Paper Title: Visualization Guardrails: Designing Interventions Against Cherry-Picking in Interactive Data Explorers
List of Authors: Maxim Lisnic, Zach Cutler, Marina Kogan, Alexander Lex
Short Description: The rise of interactive time series exploration platforms has made it easier for the general public to visualize data related to public interest, while also facilitating the creation of misleading visualizations through cherry-picked data. This study explores the potential of visualization design to combat cherry-picking—a common tactic used to misrepresent data—by developing a design space of guardrails aimed at discouraging this practice. Through crowd-sourced experiments, the researchers evaluate the effectiveness of these guardrails.

Paper Title: Accessible Text Descriptions for UpSet Plots
List of Authors: Andrew McNutt, Maggie McCracken, Ishrat Jahan Eliza, Daniel Hajas, Jake Wagoner, Nate Lanza, Jack Wilburn, Sara Cream-Regehr, Alexander Lex
Short Description: In our paper, we generate human readable Text Description for UpSet Plots and we use ReVISit to evalute user experience with the generated text description. We used the tool for survey in Prolific.

List of Authors: Zach Cutler, Lane Harrison, Carolina Nobre, Alexander Lex
Short Description: We ran two studies with revisit. The first study showed participants a few interactive charts and had them answer questions about the data, and the second showed participants static visualizations with associated captions and asked them if they trusted the data.

Paper Title: Promises and Pitfalls: Using Large Language Models to Generate Visualization Items
List of Authors: Yuan Cui, W Ge Lily, Yiren Ding, Lane Harrison, Fumeng Yang, Matthew Kay
Venue: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
Short Description:
This paper investigates the potential for large language models (LLMs) to automate the generation of multiple-choice visualization items. We develop the VILA
(Visualization Items Generated by Large LAnguage Models) pipeline, for efficiently generating visualization items that measure people’s ability to accomplish visualization task.

Paper Title: Accessible Text Descriptions for UpSet Plots
List of Authors: A. McNutt, M. K. McCracken, I. J. Eliza, D. Hajas, J. Wagoner, N. Lanza, J. Wilburn, S. Creem-Regehr, A. Lex
Short Description: This paper presents a system for automatically generating accessible text descriptions for UpSet plots, aiming to make complex set data visualizations understandable for blind and low-vision users and potentially benefiting sighted users as well.

Paper Title: SummShaper: Empowering Analysts to Tailor Attributed Summaries
List of Authors: Lane Harrison , Melissa Evans , R. Jordan Crouser , Razieh Fathi , Yue “Ray” Wang , Hilson Shrestha , and Bijesh Shrestha
Venue: 2024 Summer Conference on Applied Data Science Technical Report
Short Description: This project investigates analysts' behaviors and goals when interacting with attributed summaries, utilizing interactive prototypes and collected data to understand how summary usage aligns with goals such as time-saving, highlighting key takeaways, or answering lookup questions.

Paper Title: ReVISit 2: A Full Experiment Life Cycle User Study Framework
List of Authors: Zach Cutler, Jack Wilburn, Hilson Shrestha, Yiren Ding, Brian Bollen, Khandaker Abrar Nadib, Tingying He, Andrew McNutt, Lane Harrison, Alexander Lex
Venue: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics (VIS)
Short Description: To demonstrate the capability of reVISit 2.0 we run three replication studies on just noticable difference (perception), the role of seach (interaction), and designing textures (provenance).
Study Type: Interaction, Perception / Visual Encoding, Visualization Technique

Paper Title: Tell Me Without Telling Me: Two-Way Prediction of Visualization Literacy and Visual Attention
List of Authors: Minsuk Chang, Yao Wang, Huichen Will Wang, Yuanhong Zhou, Andreas Bulling, Cindy Xiong Bearfield
Short Description: Based on data from a 235-participant user study covering three visualization tests (mini-VLAT, CALVI, and SGL), we show that distinct attention patterns in visual data exploration can correlate with participants' literacy levels: While experts (high-scorers) generally show a strong attentional focus, novices (low-scorers) focus less and explore more.

Paper Title: Investigating the Task Load of Investigating the Task Load in Visualization Studies
Venue: alt. vis workshop in IEEE VIS 2025
Short Description: This paper conducts an online survey to investigate the task load of administering different versions of the NASA-TLX in a meta-study.
